FlavorTextOption.Text: Drengin Tree
Exploitation
Use our knowledge to get what we desire.
With this Terran hyperdrive invention, we can bend space around our ships and accelerate them at incredible speeds. Conquering the stars just got a lot easier. Bad move Terrans.
Xeno Slavery

Keeping the slavelings alive and healthy on these awful alien planets seems like a pointless task. But it's not! Because we need the slaves to make things, we must kill them for aesthetic reasons only.
Mechanized Slavery
By giving our slavelings powerful and dangerous tools, we can manufacture goods and chew up slaves at greater rates than ever before.
Labor Management
If we waste even a few less slavelings, we can make things faster or cheaper. Don't worry. We will still waste lots of slavelings.
Optimized Chain Gangs
By turning the slavelings against each other, competing for food or nicer whips, we can increase their work rate and our manufacturing capacity.
Slave Longevity
Modified whipping techniques - we stopped aiming at the head, basically - have dramatically improved slaveling survivability and reduced our manufacturing costs.
Slavery Focus
If we start using the slavelings for the jobs they're best at, or even breeding them that way, we can make everything more efficient.
Military Industry

Some of our weirder slavelings have a natural inclination to working on weapon systems. By finding these strange loners and whipping them in the right direction, we can improve our weapons manufacturing ability.
Social Industry

By continually putting the weakest and ugliest slavelings in the most dangerous roles, we can thin out their numbers, resulting in a slave population that is much better looking and effective at manufacturing.
Competitive Manufacturing
By selectively whipping every slaveling who asked for food we eventually encouraged everyone to stop asking, resulting in cheaper manufacturing centers.
Slave Masters
Mastery of slave manufacturing techniques.
Our manufacturing capacity has reached its absolute peak. We're squeezing the most out of our slavelings, occasionally literally.
Persuasive Research
Some of our slavelings, with gentle encouragement, can be made into excellent researchers. We theorize they will become smarter still with harsh whipping.
Researcher Motivation
Forces our smart slavelings to be smarter. Or cheaper.
Getting more smarts out of the smart slavelings is tricky because of how fragile they are.
Creative Motivation
Our smartest slavelings don't seem to like pain, and we've found a great way to put that to use!
Creative Living
It turns out that when we pack our researchers' kennels closer together, they're better able to share ideas.
Creative Resources
By making our least effective research slavelings into test subjects, we encourage better research and also save an awful lot of money on test subjects.
Research Extraction

Some of our research slavelings have been holding out on us! They save their smartest thoughts for plans of escape and eating! So we have found a way to just suck the ideas from their brains. Sometimes they even survive the experience.
Extraction Focus
Getting the most out of research slavelings is an art. It's just not one that they like very much.
Focused Research
By focusing our efforts on pure research we have been able to get a significant improvement on the rate of new discoveries.
Research Production Focus
By focusing our efforts on our research infrastructure we have been able to cut down the cost of building new facilities.
Research Economics
By focusing how our researchers work and eliminating some of the more wasteful experiments, we have been able to significantly reduce the maintenance of our research facilities.
Intelligence Amplification
Boosts the intelligence of slaves.

Applying powerful electrical currents to a slaveling's head was at first just a fun hobby. But by doing it in a very specific way, it can apparently make our slavelings far more intelligent. It still thankfully causes a great deal of pain.
Mysterious Knowledge
Allows construction of reduced torture research facilities.
Our wisest and weakest slavelings predict that we will be able to research even faster if we torture them less. This is a dangerous idea which we will pursue very carefully.
Pain-Free Understanding
Allows construction of torture-free research facilities.
Our untortured research slavelings have made remarkable progress unlocking the mysteries of the universe. Were we wrong to torture them for so long?
We were wrong to stop torturing the slavelings! We tried torturing them even harder and look what they came up with! Ascension will allow us new dimensions to spread misery!
Slave Coordination
Letting the slaves talk is dangerous but necessary.

We don't like when slavelings talk to each other. This is the cause of much whipping. But for the research slaves, sometimes they research better when they talk. This is problematic, but we will let more talking happen for now.
Neuro Linking
Link slave brains together.
By linking slaveling's brains together in a virtual research matrix, they can research even better. We have to create new virtual whips, but that is its own type of fun.
We must whip these new planets into shape.
Many of the new planets we visit and conquer are garbage planets filled with poison. Soon though, we will beat them into submission.
Forces planets to be better.
Making planets better and more productive is way less fun than conquering them, but it's also pretty important.
Force planets to make more food.
By shouting at the soil and threatening it with beatings and harsh fertilizers, we can improve plant crop production. Plant crops are horrible tasting, but they keep the slavelings alive at least.
Force planets to make more slavelings.
By making simple adjustments to the size and shape of our slave pits, we can encourage the slavelings to make new slavelings faster.
Force planets to be more productive.
By installing structures across the landscape that display motivational messages in towering pillars of fire, we can motivate our slavelings to work harder. And certainly hotter.
Adapt our livestock to alien environments.

Unfortunately, slavelings can't just eat other slavelings - the math just doesn't work. Also, slave meat is too valuable to waste. We need other meat crops to round out our diet, and making the meat crops grow on garbage alien worlds has been tough.
Forces planets to make more food.
Making our meat crops and plant crops thrive better on alien worlds will mean more slavelings to do work.
Make our meat crops meatier.
Our meat crops need to eat more plant crops to become meatier. But they often refuse. So now we're making them eat more.
Make our meat farms more efficient.
Our meat crops are picky eaters, and don't like eating alien plants. But there are so many alien plants! So we started forcing the meat crops to eat them.
Reduces maintenance cost of meat farms.
Meat crops like lots of space to roam around and eat plant crops. But space is expensive. So we put the meat crops in cages and give them a larger cage where they can take turns roaming.
Forces our planets to make food more efficiently.
The business of meat crops is stinky, unpleasant work. But that's no reason not to take pride in it.
Make our meat crops even meatier.
Letting meat crops get meatier on their own is a slow business. By injecting nutrients directly into the meat crop's neck, they get meatier much faster.
Make meat farms even more efficient.
Our research slavelings have found a way to make meat crops more cube shaped, which lets us stack them quite a bit easier.
Reduces maintenance cost of meat farms even more.

Some of the farm slavelings have found that by being nicer to the meat crops, they stop screaming as much, making their work easier. This is a troubling concept, so we have instead given everyone earplugs instead.
Meat Trees
Allows construction of exotic meat farms.
We're now able to grow meat crops suspended on lattice-like trees, completely removing the need for grazing room. Food production is at an all time high! As is the screaming.
Forces our planets to maximize food growth.
We now make food so efficiently that our worlds overflow with spare Drengin and slavelings. Finally their stench overwhelms that of the meat crops.
Maximizes meat crop yield
Our meat crops are now a cruel mockery of nature, yielding more meat than sanity should allow. Visitors from other worlds vomit at the sight of how efficient our farms are.
Arousing Farming
Meat farms increase population growth

Our meat farms are now so cruelly efficient that the mere sight of them is incredibly arousing to most Drengin. Less so to the slavelings, but they're getting used to it. Regular tours of the farms have yielded incredible bonuses to population growth.
Understanding how alien bacteria and viruses affect Altaria-based life will be crucial if we hope to ensure our colonists' safety.
Bio Enhancement
Forces the population to be stronger and live longer.
With medical technology we can make our slavelings live longer. That sounds bad, but it means we can hurt them more, which is good. And they will make more stuff, which is better.
Begin cloning useful slavelings.

We can now clone slavelings, which means we can make more slavelings faster than ever. Also, it is an easy matter to clone only our strongest and most docile slavelings. The whipping will be less necessary, though we can still do it for fun.
Beat the planet into submission.
Ground is meant for building things on, and if it can't be built on, then that ground is insolent and needs to be beaten into submission with science. Know your place, dirt.
Force the slavelings to settle on extreme worlds.
We now have the technology to allow slavelings to survive on extreme world. Just survive though; the slavelings won't enjoy it. But that's at least half the appeal.
Force the slavelings to adapt fully to extreme worlds.
The research slavelings have found a way to make life pleasant for those living on extreme worlds. Making things more pleasant doesn't sound like us; we're not sure how this mistake happened.
Our experience forcing the slavelings to breathe water has resulted in many dead slavelings, but finally, with the help of some aggressive surgery, a few got the hang of it.
It was only a matter of time before our slavelings adapted thick enough skin to thrive on these frozen worlds. Many have also taken to wearing extra layers of skin culled from fallen slavelings.

We went through a lot of slavelings trying to make one that didn't need water. We didn't quite get there, but they now use so little that it makes no difference. They are quite dry to the touch however.
Force the slavelings to live and die on radioactive and toxic worlds. Mostly die.
Our research slavelings, the treacherous weaklings, have made it possible for other slavelings to live on radioactive and toxic worlds. The research slavelings will not be popular after this.
Force the slavelings to adapt fully to the harshest extreme worlds.
Now the people who live on the harshest of worlds don't have to suffer to do so. All suffering from this point on shall be intentional.

After much suffering and the removal of extra limbs, we now have the technology to protect our slavelings from the harsh environment of radioactive worlds. Any extra limbs will only be kept if they prove useful.
Thanks to advances in sealant and filters, our slavelings are dying at a slower rate than ever on toxic worlds. They still die a little though, so don't worry.
Make awful planets less awful.
Planets are easy to conquer but very stubborn once you conquer them because they are dumb and feel no pain. Fortunately our research slavelings are making great advances in making planets feel pain.
Batter even the unruliest land into shape.
Using the power of massive explosions and unbridled hatred, we're able to force even more land to submit to our will.
Create useful soil from almost nothing.
We can now force just about any useless part of a planet to be less useless. If it's solid enough to crash a ship into, we can probably do something with it.
Let's use continents that don't even exist yet.
Many of the planets we find have continents put in very inconvenient places, because nature is stupid. Finally we have the technology to fix its mistakes.
Gives weaklings more air, as well as better sensors and hyperdrives.
Our starship captains complain that their ships aren't good enough to see anything, and that everyone is dying because there is not enough air. These weak and breathless captains may have a point.
Forces our ships to be better in a variety of ways.
Sending warships through space is great fun, and our research slavelings have thought of several ways to do it better.
Forces our ships to be faster.
The Terrans are clever, but not so clever. There are many possible improvements to be made to this hyperdrive, to make it more useful for hunting them down.
Pushing large Support Modules through space is inherently wasteful, by miniaturizing and optimizing the larger components, we can fit more on a ship, allowing them to go farther and faster than ever.
Forces our ships to travel further.
It's always about air and food with these mewling space travelers. Always they need more of it. We shall teach them how to get by with less.
Now we can make hyperdrives that eat more.

Our research slavelings have found that by cramming ions captured during flight into our engines, our hyperdrives will move faster. They call them Ion Drives, and promise they will get us to the places we need to sunder much more quickly.
Forces our Ion Drives to be better.
Our Ion Drives require lots of fussy work by fussy slavelings to get the most out of. If we can make them - the engines - just a little more efficient, we'll need less of them - the slavelings.
Forces our ships to be faster.
Making our engines eat more ions is fussy work. The engines sometimes vomit it seems. Our engineers are starting to get the hang of it though.
Forces our drives to be cheaper.
The slavelings who make our hyperdrives have gotten so good at it that the drives now cost us less. We shall reward the slavelings with more work.
Forces our drives to be lighter.
Lighter hyperdrives used to mean that the slavelings didn't put in all the parts. But now it means that they have put in all the parts, but have just done a really good job.
Now we can stack hyperfields on top of each other.
Our research slavelings have invented a new hyperdrive that stacks speediness in a better way than before. They used longer words than that, but basically these new engines make our ships go faster.
Forces our Warp Engines to be better.
Every time we make something new, the slavelings always find new ways to improve it later. Why the slavelings can't get it right on the first try is the source of much confusion and thrashings.
Forces our ships to go faster.
The research slavelings found a way to stack hyperfields in a better way. More stackier? Anyways, this makes the ships faster.
Forces our drives to be cheaper.
The construction slavelings have found that they can use less bolts to strap in our new Warp Fields and that no-one seems to notice. Well done, construction slavelings.
Forces our drives to be lighter.

After many beatings the manufacturing slavelings admitted that they messed up, and were making our warp drives too fat. They have fixed their mistake, but oh, the beatings will not stop for some time yet.
Now we can make hyperdrives more hyper.

What is a "cascading warp field?" The research slavelings tell us it squishes space that is already squished, and you have no idea how much we had to beat them to get an answer that simple. Bottom line: they make our ships go more.
Forces our Hyperwarp Drives to be better.
The research slavelings mewl that our engines are already very powerful, and asked if we're satisfied with that? So we checked. It turns out we're not.
Forces our drives to be cheaper.
Now that our drives are so advanced, whipping the slavelings harder does not make them cost less, because it makes the slaves drop expensive parts. Instead we need to whip their families more.
Forces our drives to be lighter.
There were a lot of safety features in our drive systems that were adding unnecessary weight. That's been taken care of now, and all rejoice.
Lets us build the ultimate hyperdrives.
Stellar Folding drives squish space like space has never been squished before. Our ships now arrive at their domination destinations faster than ever before.
Forces friendly ships to be faster.
The research slavelings report that we can now squish space for other ships nearby ours. Entire fleets can be made to go faster. The research slavelings have outdone themselves this time.
Forces our ships to be more maneuverable.
The research slavelings claim we can now generate artificial gravity fields that will make our ships faster and more maneuverable in combat.
Forces enemy ships to be slower.
Our hyperfield generators are now capable of interfering with enemy ships, reducing their speed as they approach our starbases. Anyone foolish enough to attack us will have extra time to reconsider.
Forces friendly ships to be even more faster.
We can now apply our most powerful hyperfields to friendly ships, forcing even the most primitive of them to travel at great speeds. Buckle up you lazy curs.
Now we can make better tools for looking at planets.
If we want to conquer the planets - and we do, very much so - it may be useful to know where they are.
Forces our sensors to be better.
Some of the research slavelings have taken a particular interest in studying sensors, because they figure the work is safer. To keep them motivated, we'll make sure it isn't.
Forces our sensors to see further.
The research slavelings tried using a faster computer with the sensors, and report that it makes them work better. Seems kind of obvious. We'll keep an eye on those slavelings.
Forces our sensors to be cheaper.
Now that we picked out all the slavelings with crafty little fingers to make our sensor systems, we should expect to see them made for much cheaper.
Forces our sensors to be lighter.
Apparently our first generation of sensor systems used a lot of lead and rock in them. That's gone now, but we think the research slavelings were playing a prank on us.
Our looking tools have gotten more advanced again!

Now that the research slavelings have been forced to study space folding for several years, they realize that they can build sensors capable of detecting enemy ships at much greater distances than previously believed.
Forces our sensors to be better.
If we throw more research slavelings at our sensor systems, we're sure to see some improvements in their efficiency. Not literally throwing, but actually... sure, let's try literally throwing.
Forces our sensors to see further.

Our naval officers report that there were several basic mistakes in our latest sensors. We've fixed those, and extended our sensor range. We're still deciding what to do with the research slavelings. Some kind of shame-based clothing, perhaps.
Forces our sensors to be cheaper.
The slavelings responsible for making sensors have found a way to make them cheaper. It is cute the way they try to please us.
Forces our sensors to be lighter.

We have discovered that the research slavelings have been purposefully making our sensors inefficient, so that they can later make the sensors lighter and themselves look good. This is clever, and shall be rewarded with a clever punishment.
Our looking tools are now very good looking.
The research slavelings say that we can now see in subspace, which is a place that exists, but not very well. This will let our ships now see things they mean to shoot from much further away.
Forces our sensors to be better.

The research slavelings complain that we can't see any further because of the nature of this universe. We have ordered the universe be whipped, but in the meantime, have found a few more efficiencies we could implement.
Forces our sensors to be cheaper.

The sensor making slavelings have found even more cost savings we can make in the construction of our sensors. They are adorable, these sensor making slavelings, and are becoming our empire's favorite pets.
Forces our sensors to be lighter.
"MAKE THE SENSORS LIGHTER, YOU SCUM!" we shouted. "DO IT NOW!" we added. And you know, it worked? Sometimes you don't need to over think these things.
Lets us build targeting and stealth modules.

Our ships were not slaughtering as much as they should have, so we made them enhanced targeting systems. At the same time they were being slaughtered more than they should have, so we made them a system which confuses enemy sensors.
Lets us build fleet-wide targeting and jamming modules.
The sensor systems we designed for making our ships slaughter better (and stop being slaughtered) can now benefit an entire fleet of vessels.
Forces Precursor research to be better.

A powerful race called the Precursors once called this space home. We don't know where they went, although suspect they fled when they heard we were coming. Regardless, we now are able to scavenge their relics for useful secrets.
Forces Precursor research to be better.
The research slavelings we put in charge of studying Precursor artifacts report that they require more resources to unlock their secrets. This had better be worth it, research slavelings.
Forces Precursor Relics to be more useful.
These Precursor relics have a number of confusing benefits on our society. Although we don't really understand how this is occuring, we should force them to be better at it.
Forces Precursor relic research to be better.

These Precursor artifacts are confusing to use, and most assume we have a completely different anatomy. We have ordered surgical procedures for the research slavelings to begin addressing this problem.
Forces Precursor relic cultural benefits to be better.
The slavelings seem fascinated at the very idea of a race that was more powerful than us. Perhaps they entertain dreams of being rescued. We shall encourage these dreams for now, to boost morale.
Forces Precursor relic economic benefits to be better.
Some parts of Precursor relics are apparently useless, though they do glow and shimmer with strange lights. We shall sell these fragments to the easily distracted.
Forces Precursor research to be better.
The study of Precursor relics requires very specialized equipment and very specialized research slavelings. The ones with eyes that are slightly too small seem to do best at this work.
Forces Precursor research to be better.

The research slavelings have tried recreating Precursor technology with occasionally disastrous results. For example, several have disappeared entirely. Still, if we keep this up, the benefits to us could be immeasurable.
Forces Precursor research to be better.

We're now capable of plundering Precursor relics completely, and are probably as powerful as the Precursors were themselves. It is good for them that they're not around for us to have tried tasting them.
Better life support systems makes our ships go further.
Improving our life support systems will lead to improved ship's range and less mewling from the families of crews who have suffocated in space.
Forces our life support systems to be better.

Improving our life support systems is one of those things which sounds unnecessary, but really isn't. We need those life support systems to enable our life reduction systems to get where they need to go.
Forces our ships to travel further.

It turns out that our life support systems coming out of the factories didn't have the air recyclers turned on! Those silly manufacturing slavelings. We've fixed that now, giving our ships a much needed range boost.
Forces our life support systems to be cheaper.
We've begun making our life support systems out of cheaper parts, because who is going to stop us?
Forces our life support systems to be lighter.
"Are all these parts really necessary?" we asked the research slavelings of our life support systems. They were, but we removed a few anyways.
Advanced life support forces our crew to do more with less.
The trick to life support is to stop letting the crew decide what and when to eat. They will eat dense sludge. When we use fields to pipe it directly into their mouths.
Forces our life support systems to be better.

We stationed a huge Drengin with an axe in the research labs, standing there, not saying a word. Almost immediately the researchers saw several places to improve our sensors. What a lucky coincidence.
Forces our ships to travel further.
Sometimes a crew member would close their mouth when we piped food into it, making a mess and wasting food. So we've started removing the crew member's jaw muscles, leading to improved efficiency.
Forces our life support systems to be cheaper.

Some of the research slavelings found a way to make the nutrient sludge taste better. "Does it cost money?" we asked. It didn't. "Would the sludge be cheaper if it tasted worse?" It would. So we did that instead.
Forces our life support systems to be lighter.
If we simply turn one of the dials down on the life support systems, they use less food and are lighter than ever. Also, the crews now come back from space quite a bit lighter.
Exotic life support systems feed our crews less than ever.
The Promethion Support System extends our support field methodology to its logical conclusion, and now pipes nutrients directly into our crews' necks.
Forces our life support systems to be better.
Making our life support systems better helps make our ships better, but more importantly, it also helps humiliate our ships' crewmembers.
Forces our life support systems to be cheaper.
To make our life support systems cheaper, we continually threaten the research slavelings with personally testing them. You would not believe the speed with which they come up with ideas.
Forces our life support systems to be lighter.
We can't make our ships' crews eat any less, because they would die, and we still kind of need them. But we can make the systems that deliver the food lighter and flimsier.
Lossless life support systems humiliate our crews more than ever.
Making the crews eat their own waste was a moment of genius. The research slavelings will be absolutely despised for coming up with this one.
Support fields extend the range of an entire fleet.

With only sludge and fields to move the sludge around in, there's no reason life support can't be handled by external vessels. And sludge delivery probes sent by an appropriately equipped facility should extend our range even further.
Advanced support fields extend a fleet's range even more.

We can now generate Promethion support fields in crews' necks at a great distance, allowing our fleet-support vessels to do most of the work. And our starbase life support extension modules can now fire sludge probes further than ever before.
In orbit we can make bigger, meaner ships.

It takes special training for a slaveling to be able to construct things in orbit. And, we eventually discovered, helmets. But now that we've gone to the expense, we should be able to build bigger ships than ever.
Forces our slavelings to be better at doing things in orbit.
So it turns out that if we tie the orbital slavelings on to things, they can't float away as easy. This leash technology should open the door to a bunch of possible improvements.
Force our Starports to work better.
We're getting better at building ships, which is good, because we're going to need a lot of them.
Force our infrastructure to be more efficient.
Moving things around in orbit is complicated and requires very intelligent slavelings making very big calculations. We've started yelling at them to make the calculations better.
Forces our ships to be packed tighter.
We have an awful lot of pain to bestow upon the stars, so the more pain we can pack in our ships, the better.
Lets us build medium hulls.
Making ships in orbit is tough because when construction workers fall off the thing they never stop falling. But if it means we'll be able to build bigger ships, screw 'em.
Forces our ships to be better.
Now that we go through less slavelings when making things in space, we've discovered that some of the older and wiser ones are full of good ideas.
Forces our ships to be tougher.

The slavelings had several ideas how to make our hulls stronger, so we whipped them until they shut up. But then after thinking about it for a bit, we tried listening to them. This was a good idea, and we feel proud of it.
Forces our ships to be cheaper.
It's so much harder to threaten a slaveling when that slaveling has a powerful cutting torch. But we've found a way, and now our starports will be just a little bit more efficient at making ships.
Forces our ships to be packed tighter.
Space on ships is valuable, so we've forced the crew to have less for themselves. They will now work where they sleep which is also where they eat and make waste.
Lets us build large hulls.
It's taken a lot of work, a few collapsed hulls, and many missing slavelings, but we're now finally able to build large hulls.
Forces our ships to be better.
Building super big ships is super fun and arousing. The more we think about it, the more clever ideas we get, which only excites us more.
Forces our ships to be tougher.

The research slavelings believe that by introducing micro-cavities in the structure of our hulls, they will collapse in predictable ways, making them tougher. This seemed like a trick, but after much whipping, they assure us it isn't.
Forces our ships to be cheaper.
By simply giving our construction slavelings less air in their helmets, we've been able to make them work much faster and more efficiently.
Forces our ships to be packed tighter.
It turned out that we can cram more things into our ships if we just push harder.
Lets us build huge hulls.
We're now able to build massive ships, that would make the stars themselves tremble if they had any sense.
Forces our ships to be better.
With our ships as big as they are, often the biggest construction challenge is making sure the slavelings don't get lost. Our new "buddy system" should lead to some more construction efficiencies.
Forces our ships to be cheaper.
Ships as big as the ones we're making have a lot of corners to be cut.
Forces our ships to be packed tighter.
Our ships are more crammed with death than ever before. Why would you cram them with anything else?
Forces our hulls to be tougher.
We've found a way to cram strengthening fields into the hulls of our vessels, which should make them tougher, or at the very least, chewier.
Lets us build hull support and repair modules.

A hilarious industrial accident has revealed to our construction slavelings that the same field technology we use to strengthen our ships can be used to straighten damaged beams, thus partially repairing them.
Lets us build tactical repair modules.

The research slavelings finally invented friends for themselves, so naturally we're taking those friends away and sending them into battle. These tiny little self-replicating robots will be capable of repairing damage during combat.
Lets us build carrier modules.

Carrier combat comes naturally to the Drengin, as all understand that the more Drengin shooting the better, even if some of those Drengin are in very small, very delicate ships that don't often come back.
Forces our carriers to be better.
Throwing more Drengin at a problem is a good way to solve or at least annihilate that problem. We should make our carriers better to do just that.
These little drones are fast and deadly, and more importantly cheap. They also have the added advantage of not requiring a crew, which saves lives.
These tuff little drones will guard our Support and Capital ships to the end, and when they are destroyed, no lives are lost.
Lets us build high capacity carrier modules.
Once we design the next generation of smaller, more compact fighters, and begin selecting smaller, more compact pilots, we should be able to stack more of them into the same space.
Forces Logistics to be better. Lets us build mining facilities.
Logistics is so boring. We would make it a punishment, but if the people who do it are idiots then everything is made worse. So we put the most boring slavelings in charge of it. That seems to work.
Forces various logistical operations to be better.
Shooting things in space is great. But to do that we have to move a lot of things around first. Like, a lot. This is boring. But if we don't get good at it, we won't get to shoot. So we're stuck.
Forces Logistics to be better.
It turns out that the slavelings whose eyes are a little too close together are the best at logistics, so we've begun sifting them out of the pits and sending them into space.
Forces mines to be more productive.

Asteroid mining sounds great, because it involves blasting the crap out of something. But it turns out there are all these details, and it's actually super boring. Anyways. We put some boring slavelings in charge of the details. That seems to help.
Forces starports to decay less.
Starports don't just stay there being starports. They're always breaking down, which is crap. We put some boring slavelings in charge of making that not happen, which seems to have helped a bit.
Forces Logistics to be way better.

Unlike most species, it turns out the Drengin actually have an unusual aptitude for logistics, so long as it's framed in the context of deploying massive fleets of warships. The galaxy trembles at our orderly might!
Forces Logistics to be better still.
Now that we know how good logistics is at letting us dominate things, our logistics slavelings are celebrated throughout our culture. All compete for the honor of whipping them to logistic better.
Forces Logistics to be the best.
We can put more ships more places in the galaxy than ever before. What those ships will be used for is anyone's guess, although they'd better guess quick because those ships are about to shoot them.
Lets us build mining facilities.
Blowing up asteroids is easy, but blowing them up to get useful things out of them is not. There is too much thinking involved with it, so we let specialized mining slavelings do that for us.
Forces our mining facilities to be better.
The mining slavelings have gotten better at their jobs, probably because their jobs are super dangerous and they kept dying. Now, along with not dying, they mine more resources than ever before.
Lets us build highly efficient extractors.
The research slavelings have come up with an invention that will put many mining slavelings out of work: drones capable of independently mining resources.
Lets us build targeted resource extractors.

With the right sensing equipment, and targeted nanoscale extractor heads, now even the rarest resources can be feasibly targeted for extraction. Still by mining slavelings working in cramped, hellish conditions though.
Conquest
War isn't the only thing we're good at. But we are really good at it.
Lets us build basic guns.
Putting ships in space is pointless if those ships can't shoot other ships out of space.
Forces our weapons to be better.
If we focus our research on a specific way of spreading space-based misery and destruction, we'll probably be able to spread it faster.
We have increased the targeting systems of our existing weapons substantially, and what we have learned will apply to future weapons systems.
We have reduced the mass of our existing weapons systems, and what we have learned will apply to future weapons as well.
We have reduced the cost of our existing weapons systems, and what we have learned will apply to future weapons as well.
Lets us build stronger beam weapons.
Beam weapons can cut things or burn things or look pretty. They are just great and we love them.
Forces our beam weapons to be better.
Our research slavelings seem pretty sure they can use the latest generation of materials to make our beam weapons beamier. They used more technical language though.
Forces our beam weapons to do more damage.
Our research slavelings have created a new type of focusing crystal that makes our beam weapons even more damaging. Well done research slavelings, well done.
Forces our beam weapons to be cheaper.
If there's a downside to beam weapons - and we still love them either way - it's their cost. We've been whipping the research slavelings steadily to see what they can do about that.
Forces our beam weapons to be lighter.
There was an awful lot of unnecessary shielding around our beam weapons which we've ordered the slavelings to get rid of. No-one's supposed to be standing near those things when they go off anyways.
Lets us build advanced beam weapons.
Drengin have been using simple matter disruption weapons for centuries, because of our advanced capacity for causing pain. It took very little work to adapt these into ship-based weapons.
Forces our beam weapons to be better.
Making our beam weapons better, or at the very least brighter, is a great way to spread the good news about Drengin inventiveness to other races in the galaxy.
Forces our beam weapons to do more damage.
The research slavelings seem very excited about the latest advances in crystallography, claiming we'll soon be able to put much more energy into our beam weapons.
Forces our beam weapons to be cheaper.

The weapons slavelings have always claimed they needed a lot of time to individually tune each weapon as it was made. We suspected they were just being lazy. We were right. The weapons will be made faster and cheaper from now on.
Forces our beam weapons to be lighter.
Our weapons slavelings have found a better way to wrap the charge coils of our beam weapons, making them more efficient, and making room for more of them.
Lets us build extra deadly beam weapons.
Plasma is deadly stuff, and we went through many slavelings trying to figure out first how to contain it, and then how to point it away from the user. Their sacrifice is already forgotten.
Forces our beam weapons to be better.
Our puny research slavelings claim that physics prevents our beam weapons from becoming more efficient. "So invent new physics!" we shouted. They're working on it now.
Forces our beam weapons to be cheaper.
Making containment chambers for plasma weapons is slow, dangerous work. So we've ordered the slavelings to do it more quickly to minimize the danger.
Forces our beam weapons to be lighter.

Our weapons slavelings have found a way to make our beam weapons even lighter. "It is weird that the research slavelings did not do this," they say. "You should punish them." Oh those treacherous slavelings.
Lets us build face-meltingly powerful beam weapons.
The research slavelings have outdone themselves this time, inventing a weapon which can evaporate enemy ships entirely. Our research slavelings are growing perhaps too powerful.
Lets us build the ultimate beam weapons.
The research slavelings are beginning to frighten us. Doom Rays are even more powerful than the phasers they're based on, capable of annihilating non-trivial parts of the universe.
Forces a fleet's beam weapons to be better.

Beam weapons are so appealing to Drengin sensibilities that we have mastered their use far in advance of the weaker species. For example, by augmenting their storage systems with an external field, we can increase the beam output of an entire fleet.
Forces a fleet's beam weapons to be extra better.

The research slavelings have found a way to reduce the effectiveness of enemy shields, and to absorb enemy beam attacks directed at our own vessels. The research slavelings will receive a congratulatory beating for their hard work.
Forces a fleet's beam weapons to be much extra better.
We've found a way to make our fleet beam support systems even better. They didn't even need to be told to do this, that's how well the research slavelings know we like beam weapons.
Lets us build better missiles.
Missile weapons are simple, but there is nothing wrong with that. Destroying things doesn't always have to be this whole big thing.
Forces our missile systems to get better.
We have annihilated thousands of asteroids, target drones, and, accidentally, target range slavelings, and have come up with a number of possible improvements for our missiles.
Forces missile launchers to shoot faster.
Our weapons slavelings found a way to put more missiles into the missile launchers, meaning they can shoot faster now.
Forces missiles to be cheaper.
Now we can make more missiles for less, which will be perfect for sharing with flimsy alien ships.
Forces missiles to be lighter.
If we make the missile launchers lighter, we can put more missile launchers on our ships. If we put more missile launchers on our ships there will be less enemy ships. Math is fun.
Lets us build angrier missiles.
The Drengin are masters of things that go boom, and missiles are no exception. We've leaped well in front of the rest of the galaxy in our ability to blow up the rest of the galaxy.
Forces our missile systems to get better.
The research slavelings seem to think that if we pay attention to the warheads of our missile systems we'll get better booms.
Forces missile launchers to shoot farther.

The weapons slavelings seem to think that linked periods of acceleration and coasting will allow our missiles to blow things up from further away. If they're wrong they shall be blown up from close range.
Forces missiles to be cheaper.
After many weapons slavelings mysteriously disappeared in clouds of smoke, we finally mastered the latest generation of explosives. All of our missiles should now be much cheaper to make.
Forces missiles to be lighter.

Shaped-charge warheads mean we can make each individual missile lighter, leaving more room for other missile launchers or whatever else we want to carry. Probably still going to be more missile launchers if we're honest.
Lets us build exotic missiles.
The research slavelings have found a way for our warheads to use high energy bursts of photons to pierce an enemy's hull at the moment of impact. Our missiles are now much more dangerous. And pretty.
Forces our missile systems to get better.

We think we can make our missiles a bit cheaper and lighter still. The cost to our research slavelings time will be considerable, but we've ensured they don't have any hobbies, so they're ready to go.
Forces missiles to be cheaper.
After many beatings and demonstration "missile rides" for disobedient slavelings, our missile manufacturing process is now almost perfectly efficient.
Forces missiles to be lighter.
The research slavelings have found that our warheads can be made more efficient. "More powerful?" we asked. But no. Just lighter. Which is good, but we beat them anyways.
Lets us build crazy dangerous missiles.
They used a lot of big words - wide-spectrum, photon-encasement, bang - but the basic idea the research slavelings were trying to get across is that we have a new type of super deadly missile.
Lets us build world ending missiles.
The research slavelings may have gone a little far this time. Missiles that contain small singularities? Yikes. Still, let's fire a few off at some weaklings just to see if they work.
Forces a fleet's missile weapons to be better.

Once we started shooting missiles at things, we liked it. A lot. Using Drengin ingenuity, our military technicians found a way to improve the tracking and range of the missiles, giving us a huge advantage over punier races.
Forces a fleet's missile weapons to be extra better.
The research slavelings have thought of a way to make our missiles work better against coward aliens who hide behind point defense systems.
Forces a fleet's missile weapons to be much extra better.
Our research slavelings have found a way to completely neutralize an enemy's point defense systems. Which is good, because we were really starting to hate those things.
Lets us build better kinetic weapons
Kinetic weapons will tear holes in the ships and faces of those who stand in the way of Drengin might, and also anyone standing directly behind those people.
Forces our kinetic weapons to get better.
Making our kinetic weapons better will turn the food species into food faster
Forces our kinetic weapons to shoot further.
The research slavelings have found a way to extend the range of our kinetic weapons using smaller projectiles, bigger magnets, and tricky math.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be cheaper.
The slavelings responsible for making weapons have found a way to make electromagnets without getting crushed by the electromagnets. We go through far less slavelings while making them now.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be lighter.
After much whipping, the research slavelings have found several ways to save weight on our kinetic weapons. They should have done this in the first place, and have been whipped for their insolence.
Lets us build more deadly kinetic weapons.
Pulse cannons are the latest way we have of making things into smaller things. Our intelligence slavelings report that we are far ahead of the rest of the galaxy in this important field.
Forces our kinetic weapons to get better.

The research slavelings are very excited about the latest superconductors. They are an excitable bunch. Then they said the superconductors will make our kinetic weapons better. Now everyone's excited.
Forces our kinetic weapons to shoot further.

Smaller projectiles sound like a bad thing, and many research slavelings were whipped for suggesting it. But if they go faster and shoot further, that's a good thing. Many research slavelings were whipped for explaining this.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be cheaper.
We've found a source of components that are so durable that not even our incompetent manufacturing slavelings can damage them, making our kinetic weapons cheaper to make.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be lighter.
The research slavelings have invented new low-resistance electromagnets that will give our kinetic weapons a lot more ouch per weight.
Lets us build very dangerous kinetic weapons.
Our newest guns can shoot pulses of gravitons at things we don't like, which can rip apart those things from the inside. That will teach them to be more likable.
Forces our kinetic weapons to get better.
The research slavelings have been whipped to the brink of sanity, and report back that our kinetic weapons are just about as good as they can be. We'll whip them a smidge more, just to be sure.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be cheaper.
We recently discovered that the weapons manufacturing slavelings were working slowly because working around massive electromagnets was dangerous and they wanted to live. We've put a stop to that.
Forces our kinetic weapons to be lighter.
With much whipping and yelling and breaks for frozen treats, we've coaxed the research slavelings into shaving a bit more weight off of our kinetic weapons.
Lets us build impossibly deadly kinetic weapons.
Quantum Drivers will let us shoot our future food sources with mass that doesn't even exist yet.
Lets us build the ultimate kinetic weapons.

We're not sure how the research slavelings are able to make micro singularities, and are a little worried that they know how and we don't. But for the time being, they're willing to share, and they're great for shooting at things we hate.
Forces a fleet's kinetic weapons to be better.
We're way ahead of the rest of the food species with this invention, which makes all the kinetic weapons in a fleet more dangerous. Take that, food species.
Forces a fleet's kinetic weapons to be extra better.
The research slavelings found a way to make our fleet support systems even better. Also, now our slugs can penetrate armor better, giving the food species less places to hide.
Forces a fleet's kinetic weapons to be much extra better.
Now our kinetic weapons can fracture armor entirely, leaving the food species utterly helpless and tenderized.
Forces our military to be better.
Soldiers and guns are good and we like them. We should have more of them. And better ones! And more of them again!
Forces our soldiers to be better.

It take a lot of effort and a lot of leashes to stop Drengin from fighting and eating each other. But now that we have those leashes in place, our soldiers should be that much hungrier for the food species.
Forces our planetary defenses to be better.

If the unthinkable happens, and the food species attack us, they will soon find that even the lowliest Drengin slaveling is a match for their bravest warriors. Also, we don't feed the slavelings much, so they will be hungry.
By training our population in basic resistance tactics, we can help them be ready for anything. A prepared population can often be the difference between victory and defeat when invaded.
Lets us build transports to invade planets.
For millennia the Drengin have looked at the stars and dreamed of eating the things there. Those dreams are now a reality.
Lets us use creative invasion tactics.
When we scare the cowardly food species out of space, we'll still have to chase them down to the ground. And we should be angry at them for making us chase them.
Dropping heavy things on things has long been a favorite pastime of Drengin children. And taking it into space hasn't made it any less fun.
Information warfare sounds boring and dumb, but if we can cripple a food species' defenses before we land, they will become food far more easily.
Biological warfare is cruel and vicious and wildly immoral. But there are also downsides, for example the way it turns the food species into poison.

A greater understanding of the tactics and training required for effective ground-based combat has led to a new form of military unit which specializes in establishing beachheads in unfriendly gravity wells.
Lets us use dangerously creative invasion tactics.
Thanks to advances in unethical behavior, we have a few new options for tenderizing the ground forces of any food species.
The Drengin empire is so terrifying that even the sea trembles at the sight of our advancing transports!
Now we can make a planet suddenly experience massive, worldwide volcanic activity. This will be lots of fun and we promise to take many pictures.
Forces soldiers to be more effective and transports to carry more.
Using drone soldiers feels like cheating, robbing natural Drengin of the chance to rip an enemy's neck out themselves. But there's no denying the neck-ripping potential of these new drones.
Forces soldiers to be more effective and transports to carry more.
Our research slavelings have come up with a new type of transport which is capable of firing soldiers out of it like a gun. This lets us deploy soldiers faster and more hilariously than ever.
Provides stronger defense against planetary bombardment.
Hiding is a very un-Drenginly thing to do, but when we're hiding from things moving at several kilometers a second that are aimed directly at our heads, there's some sense to it.
Forces our defenses to be better.
If the food species dare try to attack our homes, we should be ready for them and all their tricky tricks.
Informational warfare is a cowardly way to fight, and if any food species try this on us, they won't get far. Come at us honestly, food species.
With the right vaccinations for our colonists, soon even alien bacteria and viruses will tremble at the might of Drengin immune systems!
Killing the food species before they even land on our planets is, at heart, a waste of food. But if there's lots of food to go around, it may still be worth considering.
Our research slavelings have used the properties of hemispheres to encase our most valuable buildings in powerful shields, protecting them from orbital bombardment.
Lets us build defensive systems for our ships.

We can't pretend that the food species will be happy to find out that they're food. Many of them might even fight back. And that's part of the fun! We should just be able to not die when they do that.
Forces our ships to die less quickly.
Giving a ship something that isn't a gun is a confusing idea. But if it lets them use their guns more, then that's ok we guess.
Forces our shields to be cheaper.
Although we want to keep our ship's crews alive, there's no reason we need to spend too much money on it. They don't need to be spoiled.
Reduces cost of point defenses.
Our point defenses are better at shooting down missiles now, because someone finally explained to the research slavelings about the importance of "leading" a target.
Forces our armor to be lighter.
We were able to save a lot of weight on our armor systems by putting real cheap stuff over the crew quarters.
Lets us build better shield systems.
Shields are even better at stopping enemy attacks than deflector fields. Our ship captains have no more excuse for dying now.
Forces our shields to be better.
The research slavelings have reviewed reports of how our shield systems have behaved in battle, and come up with several possible improvements we can make.
Forces our shields to be stronger.

The ship's crews pointed out that if we make their shields stronger that they'd die less. "And?" we said. Then they said they'd be able to kill more. "There you go," we said. Anyways, their shields are a little stronger now.
Forces our shields to be cheaper.
Spending less money on shields is good because it means more money for other things. Weapons, basically.
Forces our shields to be lighter.

Completely by accident, one of our manufacturing slavelings invented a more efficient type of field generator for our shields. He has been promoted to research slaveling and received a congratulatory whipping.
Lets us build really great shield systems.
Barrier Fields are capable of absorbing some of the energy of weapon strikes. Now, when the food species try to kill us it just makes our shields stronger and us angrier.
Forces our shields to be better.
We brought in some new research slavelings who say they can do a better job with our shields than the old ones, and the old ones should be beaten. No love lost amongst those slavelings.
Forces our shields to be stronger.
Our first Barrier Field systems occasionally exploded violently. We think this was because the research slavelings were playing a prank. We've fixed that now and scolded the research slavelings.
Forces our shields to be cheaper.
The manufacturing slavelings have found a few ways to make shield systems cheaper than ever before. They will be beaten for their excellence.
Forces our shields to be lighter.
With some new inventions called super conductors, our shield systems are lighter than ever. The research slavelings should have invented those a long time ago.
Lets us build exotic shield systems.
Our latest shields can focus their energy on the point of enemy attack, making them much stronger than before. The stupid food species can't hurt us now.
Forces our shields to be better.
We brought back the old research slavelings because they claimed that if we whipped their replacements enough, they could find a way to improve the shields some more.
Forces our shields to be cheaper.
Our manufacturing slavelings are so good at their jobs that we can now use less of them to make the same number of shields. The extra slavelings will be sent on vacation. To the mines.
Forces our shields to be lighter.

Our shields are now as light as they will ever be according to the research slavelings. They say that kind of thing a lot, but always change their mind after more whipping. We shall proceed as per normal then.
Lets us build the best shield systems.
The research slavelings promise that these new shields will make our ships "basically invulnerable." Any ships that die with these shields will result in much punishment for the research slavelings.
Lets us build shield support systems.
We now have a system which lets us boost the shields of an entire fleet. Drengin fleets just became even worse news for the food species.
Lets us build better shield support systems.
We found a way to make our fleet shield supports even better. We're so good at war now that we don't even really have to try any more.
Lets us build better point defense systems.
More guns sounds like a great idea, but it turns out that these guns are just for shooting other guns, which makes them just an ok idea.
Forces our point defenses to be better.
There are still a number of ways we can optimize our point defense systems, if we're willing to spend the effort on cowardly defensive technology, that is.
Forces our point defenses to be better.
As soon as we stopped using our cheapest railguns for point defense systems, they started working better.
Forces our point defenses to be cheaper.
There's no reason to spend so much money on keeping ship's crews alive. Keeping ships alive is ok, we guess, but even then, let's not go crazy.
Forces our point defenses to be lighter.
The research slavelings realized we could use smaller slugs in our point defenses and they'd still be able to shoot the bad guys' missiles.
Lets us build even better point defenses.
Confusing enemy missiles sounds like a cowardly thing to do, but the research slavelings promise that its actually smart, and that it will make our ships tougher to kill.
Forces our point defenses to be better.
After locking them in a room with highly powerful transmitters for a few days, the research slavelings all have headaches, as well as a number of clever ways for improving our ECM systems.
Forces our point defenses to be better.
The treacherous food species are always looking for ways to shoot us. Stronger point defenses should help stop that.
Forces our point defenses to be cheaper.
Our first counter measure systems were clumsy and expensive to make. Now that the manufacturing slavelings have some practice at it, they can make them much cheaper. And they'd better.
Forces our point defenses to be lighter.
The manufacturing slavelings have gotten very good at finding ways to save weight in these counter measure systems. It is good to see them taking pride in their horrible, degrading work.
Lets us build exotic point defenses.
We've tried installing our point defense systems on drones. Although it feels bad giving guns to a drone, at least they can do all their shooting and exploding at a safe distance from our ships.
Forces our point defenses to be better.
If we can make our drone systems even a little more efficient, we should be able to see significant cost or weight savings. Which is almost as good as researching a new gun, we suppose.
Forces our point defenses to be cheaper.
The nice thing about using drones in combat roles is that they don't complain when you cut corners on the equipment you provide them.
Forces our point defenses to be lighter.

A mistake by the manufacturing slavelings resulted in the point defense drones going out with a lot of parts. But it didn't make any difference at all in their performance. The manufacturing slaves have been both punished and rewarded for their mistake.
Lets us build the ultimate point defenses.

The research slavelings have taken everything they know about cowering and equipped our new Aereon drones with the latest railguns, ECM and smart chafe. Enemy missiles tremble at the sight of a Drengin vessel now.
Lets us build fleet point defense systems.
With this new long range missile tracking system, every ship in our fleet should have even less to fear from enemy missiles than they had before.
Lets us build even better fleet point defense systems.
Entire fleets of Drengin ships can now be protected with the latest point defense attacking technology. The food species better have another type of gun handy.
Lets us build tougher armor.
Armor is simple and we like that. Put heavy things between us and the bad guy, then laugh at the bad guy. Simple. Good.
Forces our armor to be better.
Armor is good and honest and we like it. We should make it better.
Forces our armor to be stronger.
The slavelings tried bolting the armor plates on in a new way, and it seems to make our ships a bit tougher. The panels fall off way less, for one thing.
Forces our armor to be cheaper.

We went through quite a few slavelings before we realized the benefit of only using the strongest ones for armor work. But now that we have, we should be able to manufacture armor panels much more cheaply.
Forces our armor to be lighter.

Our slavelings found a way to make our armor panels fit just a little bit tighter, meaning we can use less of them. The armor panels that is. We will still, as always, continue to go through a lot of slavelings.
Lets us build way tougher armor.

When we stack certain materials on top of each other, they're much harder than just dumb old metal. The research slavelings call these new composites Durantium, and promise they'll make our ships much less explodey.
Forces our armor to be better.
Armor is getting complex, which is confusing and bad, but it keeps us alive longer, which is still good. Making it better is harder, but we should still do that.
Forces our armor to be stronger.

One of our slavelings fell in the armor forge, and his remains formed an interesting crust between two layers of the armor, making it somewhat stronger. I don't need to tell you what we did next. But we are running low on slavelings if you need a hint.
Forces our armor to be cheaper.
Now that we're using composites to make our armor, we can use weaker, cheaper slavelings to do much of the preliminary lamination work.
Forces our armor to be lighter.

We promised the research slavelings they could eat the weight savings they could find in our latest Durantium composites. They came up with a few savings, but did not seem happy when we put armor slabs in their food dishes and laughed.
Lets us build exotic armor.
Kanvium armor partially turns to fluid when shocked, giving incoming projectiles a ferocious hug that terrifies them into stopping. At least that's what we like to think is happening.
Forces our armor to be better.
Our armor is thick enough to stop all but the meanest food species from hurting us. But we can probably still make it a little lighter or cheaper.
Forces our armor to be cheaper.
We found a way to make our armor manufacturing process a little cheaper. All it took was exposing the slavelings to harsh chemicals, which feels like something we should have discovered ages ago.
Forces our armor to be lighter.
According to our manufacturing slavelings, if we make some minor changes to the design of our ships, they'll be far easier to armor. "And they'll look meaner," they added. So all right then.
Lets us build the ultimate armor.
Zero point armor is madness, and we're pretty sure the research slavelings are lying when they describe how it works. What seems undeniable though, is how tough it is.
Lets us build fleet armor-support fields.
By using the same force fields our slavelings use to make armor plating, we can create ship-based emitters that harden other ships at a distance. Drengin fleets just got a lot harder to chew.
Lets us build better fleet armor-support fields.
The research slavelings found a way to improve our hardening fields by doing something with "poles" and "science." Whatever they did, our ships are burlier than ever.
Intimidation
Lets us research technology for intimidating our food.
The other races of this galaxy will all be slaves and food for us eventually, but until that day, we may have to yell at them. And we'll need tools for doing that.
Lets us communicate with our food.
We've met enough species now to finally figure out what they mean when they flap their mouth parts in those disgusting ways. It turns out they were pleading for their lives.
Forces our words to be better.
Paying attention to the words you speak is just the most boring garbage thing to do. But if we get good at it, we might be able to convince the food species to self tenderize or something.
Forces our Diplomats to be better.

We've given our diplomats rubber masks depicting horrible alien faces, and told them to begin role-playing as the food species to better understand them. The results are hilarious, and surprisingly effective.
Spreads Drengin glory further.
By sharing Drengin culture with the food species, we can begin preparing them for their new role in our empire.

Maintaining order is difficult in a civilization this big, and even the slave masters get a bit rowdy when they're a long way from the capital. Who shall whip the whippers? A Stellar Empire essentially creates a pyramid of whipping.
How we organize all the Drengin and slavelings into an effective conquering force is very, very important, in a kind of boring way.
Slave-Master Party
A weak central government that offloads most of its power to regional overseers has certain advantages. Local taskmasters seem best suited for encouraging economic development for example.
Coddling Party

Being nice to the slavelings feels unnatural and limits our strength, although it does diminish the chance of slaveling revolts. Also, the food species in the galaxy really like it when we do this, improving our diplomatic relations.
Dominion Party
A Dominion government takes a balanced approach to governing, and attempts to dominate, humiliate, and make irate all of its citizens equally.

By giving everyone a say over the control of the government, and then making that say extremely limited, we'll ensure everyone in our civilization is happier and more productive without having to give up any actual power to do so.
Our weakest, palest slavelings have come up with a few new ways we could organize our people, which might make them better at eating the food species.
Plundering Party
If it's not going to be stripped of its resources, what good is a galaxy for? This philosophy of governing turns our whole empire towards production, and says to hell with the consequences.
Thievery Party

If we gear our civilization towards trade - especially unfair trade - we can profit greatly from the cowardly food species who we deal with. And the exposure our traders will have with the food species will make them excellent spies.
Smart Party

Our research slavelings are lovable scamps, and by dedicating all of our civilization to provide the necessary beatings to support their work, we can build up a massive technological advantage over the food species.

Democracy is an unsettling idea to the Drengin, but we can probably fake it well enough to get the same benefits. The increase in slaveling happiness and the boost to our markets will be worth the trouble.
Forces our politicians to be better.
With the right technology, we can now begin injecting our political systems directly into people's faces, making this whole politics business a lot easier, and frankly, more fun.
War Party
Allows use of the War Party.
This is what we've been building to, what all Drengin have secretly hoped for their whole lives. An entire civilization dedicated to consuming other civilizations. The mouth waters.
Pre-War Party
Allows use of the Pre-War Party.
Theoretically, a civilization could not be conducting war or trying to eat its neighbors. A so called "Pre-War" party might promote culture, social welfare, or crazy crap like that.
A Star Federation is designed to make everyone, Drengin, slaveling, and captured food species, as happy and productive as possible.
Lets us build embassies and form basic treaties.
Sometimes we might want to eat a species, but not be ready for them yet. In those cases, if we can convince the food species to not build any guns, it will make their eventual consumption easier.
Forces our treaties to be better.
Diplomatic treaties are a great way to make the food species give us things. We can then use those things for making ships that can go eat the food species. Diplomacy can be fun after all.
Something which makes us wealthy sounds good. Something which makes food races wealthy sounds bad. Treaties are tricky business.

If we can cram Drengin culture down the throats of other species, we can hope to increase the Influence we have on our neighbors and eventually make them better slavelings when we get around to conquering them.

Sharing our research data with a food species is a dangerous business, no matter what we get in return. They could use that knowledge against us. Although we could also use their knowledge against them. Tough decision.
Let us build improved diplomatic buildings. Increases Diplomacy.
Turning a food species into an ally is a tough idea to wrap our head around. But if it makes other food species easier to process, there might be some merit to it.
Forces our alliances to be better.
An alliance is a strange concept, but it essentially means a food species who we will eat last, if at all. A troubling notion, though it might make sense for some of the gristlier food species.
With a formal military alliance, we can make friendly food species fight the other kinds. Suddenly diplomacy doesn't seem so bad.
Sharing research secrets with a food species is a tough thing to consider. But if we're really sure we're not going to eat them for awhile, there might be some benefit to it.
If we can convince the friendly food species to swallow more of our ideas, we can make them so similar to the Drengin that they might not need to be eaten after all.
Lets us build advanced diplomatic buildings. Increases Diplomacy.
No-one was more surprised than we were to discover that the Drengin are considered the most respected and fair-minded people in the galaxy. People listen to our words now. Our words!
Lets us build boring civilian buildings.
Making people happy is distasteful, but it's also sadly a sometimes necessary aspect of empire building.
Forces our culture to be better.
Spending time and energy on making art things is distasteful, so the least we can do is make the art things more efficiently.
Forces others to like us more.
It took us a long time to notice, but there are people in the galaxy who don't hate us. They... like us? And now we can do things to make more of them like us, however weird and wrong that feels.
Forces our cultural buildings to be cheaper.
Spending money on culture is a garbage idea and we hate it. Building the cheapest possible buildings to house our cultural products is one way to show our disdain.
Forces cultural buildings to cost less to run.
The art slavelings mewl continuously for more supplies. So we give them less supplies. That will teach them for asking.
Lets us build improved boring civilian buildings.
Are we sure we want to dedicate so much effort to enhancing our culture? This feels wrong and dangerous. Our ancestors are surely beating their chest plates in anger and confusion.
Forces our culture to be more focused.
If we make our art things appealing to specific people, those people will like us more. They will not be given a choice.
Entertainment programs which mock the hilarious mishaps which keep happening to our research slavelings might better spread the influence of our research-heavy planets.

A culture which shows how great Drengin leadership is sounds like a great idea. We're pretty great, right? Full of fun cooking and punishment shows, this culture should see planets with high approval increase their influence.
Increases Influence on wealthy planets.
A culture which shows how great the wealthy are, eating and whipping things with much flair and style, will be immensely popular with our wealthy folk, and help spread their influence.
Lets us build advanced cultural buildings. Increases Influence.

There are certain people in the galaxy who like the Drengin way of life. "Seriously?" we ask. But yes. Anyways, if we can encourage more Drengin to travel the stars, spreading our glory, we can increase our influence.
Lets us build exotic cultural buildings. Increases Influence.
The people who arrive here from the food species are full of garbage ideas. By forcing Drengin culture into them, we can increase the penetration of our culture and influence more than ever.
Let us build the ultimate cultural buildings. Increases Influence.
Our culture is the only one in the galaxy worth considering, and all who follow a lesser path will soon be beaten or eaten by our many acolytes.
Prepares civilization for Ascension.
There are other universes out there which have yet to experience the delight of having Drengin jaws clamp around their necks. Our research and philosophy slavelings are finding ways to change that.
Forces our economy to be better.
"Targeted" economic policies makes them sound really exciting and militaristic. They're not though. They're still boring spreadsheet garbage.
Forces planets to be wealthier.
Our planets need to make more money, and we've found that by putting up billboards that promise death for everyone who isn't wealthy, we can encourage just that.
Forces planets to be happier.
Forcing people to like us is tricky business, as all of our good forcing techniques actually make people like us less. But if we use all of our forcing techniques at once, that seems to do the trick.
Forces a planet to trade more.

If we make our slavelings spend their free time manufacturing small, tradable trinkets, we should boost the trade income of a particular planet. We'll have to give the slavelings free time first, though.
Lets us build improved economic buildings.
If we build bigger and fancier buildings to make more money, we'll be able to eventually afford bigger and fancier guns to take more money. Economics is fun when you put it in terms you understand.
Lets us build advanced economic buildings.
The Drengin and clever slavelings responsible for our economy are sometimes a bit too clever. Regulations and brutal public punishments may be necessary to bring some order to our banking system.
Forces our economy to be better.
The Drengin and slavelings responsible for making money are full of clever ways to make more of it. It's almost a little unseemly.
Forces our trade routes to make more money.
By giving our traders bigger guns and twitchier eyes, we can improve their negotiating power substantially, leading to more money for us.
It turns out that if you just stop blinking during negotiations, you can get way better terms from whoever's sitting across from you. We're removing our negotiators' eyelids as we speak.
Force tourists to spend more money.
By imposing entry fees, exit taxes, gravity tariffs, and mandatory survival payments on all foreign tourists who pass through our domain, we can ensure they leave more of their money behind.
Lets us build exotic economic buildings.

It is a little worrying the degree to which some Drengin dedicate themselves to making money. Because they're still Drengin, and still completely depraved. Even more exotic regulations and punishments may be needed.
Lets us build the ultimate economic buildings.

The Drengin who believe that they can own something without pressing their boot into its neck are a confusing bunch. But they insist that this idea of a "stock market" will let them create wealth faster than ever before.
We shall send many Drengin to other planets, only not with guns, but with incredible goods. Sounds strange, but it's worth a try. They may also still carry some guns.
Forces our traders to target specific markets.
By convincing our traders to menace particular markets with threats of savings and big value, we should be able to increase our income.
By optimizing both the outgoing and receiving ends of our trade routes we have been able to achieve a modest overall profit for everyone involved.
We believe the best way to increase trade income is the establish more trade routes. With a bit of effort we have been able to stretch our recourses enough to establish one more.
Market Extortion
If we demand traders establish fixed bases to store their goods here, it will make it far easier to threaten them and then take those goods.
Trade Focus
Forces our traders to target specific markets.
We should continue inflicting the menace that are Drengin traders on specific economic sectors that we wish to ravage.
By establishing a trade tariffs on our colonies we have been able to increase our trade route profits substantially.
More trade routes, more trade income, who no need for Tariffs, or 'Luxury items', Some times its best to stick to the basics.
Lets us build advanced trading buildings. Adds two trade routes.
We were going through cargo slavelings a little too quickly, and so have developed new, advanced trading facilities with features like cranes, and safety railings.
Fighting Pits
Lets us build Fighting Pits.

There are few things more relaxing than watching two other creatures fight each other to the death, or even just to the 'really badly hurt.' Our new fighting pits should boost Approval everywhere they're built.
Tournaments
Lets us build an Arena.

By organizing our regional fighting pits into tournament brackets, and inviting the best and most depraved fighters from other nearby worlds, we can ensure that the Arena is a fun time for the entire family.
Approval Focus
Forces various planets to be happier.
Our regular program of inspirational beatings is no longer capable of delivering the approval benefits we need. We should begin targeting our inspiration more carefully.
Easy to Please
Increase the morale of your colonies.
We have discovered that we can make people feel more confident and happy. With proper messaging, we can keep our citizens happy without all that costly infrastructure.
Easily Distracted
Makes building Entertainment Improvements much cheaper.
We have discovered that our efforts in keeping our people distracted have paid off. We can now build anything, and they will think it is fun.
Eager to Please
Greatly reduces the Maintenance required by Entertainment Improvements.
Not only are our people easier to please, they will now do most of the work it takes to distract themselves, for free.
Saughtertorium
Lets us build a Slaughtertorium.

A slaughtertorium will serve as more than a means to amuse the local populace, but also attract tourists from around the galaxy who might be interested in seeing what the insides of various creatures look like.
Hunting Grounds
Lets us build Hunting Grounds.
Hunting Grounds will give particularly wealthy individuals the opportunity to hunt and kill some of the most beautiful and delicate animals from around the galaxy.
Lets us build tourism structures.
Encouraging people to come to Drengin worlds sounds like a delicious plan. Only apparently we're not supposed to eat these ones? This strange concept will supposedly make us money.
Lets us build advanced tourism structures.

Now that the galaxy knows how great Drengin is, and how unlikely they are to have their faces eaten here, we're drawing more tourists than ever before. Who would have thought that not eating faces could be so worthwhile?
Homage
Lets us build the Temple of Strength.
The Temple of Strength will inspire Drengin everywhere to be just a little bit stronger and meaner in their dealings. We expect our soldiers and childcare workers in particular to benefit from this.
Black Market
Lets us build a Black Market.
Despite our best efforts, the slavelings often come into possession of various bits of money. By giving them a place to trade, we can boost their productivity, improving manufacturing and research.
